block.p: Clashes in Jerusalem Leave Four Dead at Holy Site Four Palestinians were killed at the Temple Mount, known in Arabic as Haram al Sharif, in a second day of rioting that began when Ariel Sharon, the rightist opposition leader, visited the Muslim compound to assert Jewish claims to the site.

Clashes in Jerusalem Leave Four Dead at Holy Site Four Palestinians were killed at the Temple Mount, known in Arabic as Haram al Sharif, in a second day of rioting that began when Ariel Sharon, the rightist opposition leader, visited the Muslim compound to assert Jewish claims to the site.

Review of Diplomats' Files The State Department froze the promotions of hundreds of officials until their security records were reviewed, officials disclosed, adding that the reviews had been completed and that fewer than 10 promotions had been barred. The freeze followed the suspension of the security clearance of the ambassador to Israel, Martin S. Indyk.

Serbs Rally Against Milosevic Thousands of people across Serbia protested the continued rule of President Slobodan Milosevic, and opposition leaders called on foreign governments to examine the disputed results from the election on Sunday.

Peru Leader's Appeal to U.S. Four months after he claimed reelection in a vote widely seen as flawed, President Alberto K. Fujimori implored American officials to give him the backing needed to move Peru toward full democracy.

Turkish Journalist Freed Nadire Mater was acquitted of charges that she insulted the Turkish military in a book about the war against Kurdish separatists, in a case watched closely by advocates of press freedom and human rights.

The Politics of the Euro Denmark's rejection of a single European currency may imperil a plan by Prime Minister Tony Blair to persuade Britons to abandon the pound, and it has undermined Mr. Blair's efforts to cast Britain's euro debate in mainly economic terms.

Libyan's Diary Under Scrutiny The diary of one of two Libyans accused of bombing Pan Am Flight 103 is being studied as possible evidence by the three judges in the Lockerbie trial, who also serve as the jury.

Bush Energy Plan Favors More Domestic Exploration Gov. George W. Bush, saying the Clinton administration has been shortsighted, outlined a broad energy plan that calls for more domestic fuel production, better relations with foreign suppliers and the opening of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for drilling, all of which he framed as potential remedies for rising oil and gas prices. He also offered incentives for developing alternative energy sources and clean-burning fuels.
The Bush campaign reversed a decision to bypass the Christian Coalition's conference, saying he would address it by videotape today.

Gore Sees Danger in Bush Plan Vice President Al Gore criticized the Bush proposal to open Alaska's protected wilderness to oil drilling, saying it would bring ''decades of environmental damage to reap just a few months of increased oil supply.''

Mr. Gore's running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, went to Texas to deliver a blistering assault on Governor Bush's environmental record, depicting Texas as choking in smog and Mr. Bush as bent on ravaging the Alaskan wilderness for oil.

NBC to Offer Stations Debate NBC said it would give its 222 local television affiliates the option of broadcasting either the presidential debate or a Major League Baseball playoff game on Tuesday night. Earlier, the network said it would not broadcast the debate at all because it was committed to the playoff.

Consensus on Land Protection White House and Congressional negotiators agreed to set aside $12 billion over six years to assure a flow of money for protecting sensitive lands. It would be the largest federal land conservation effort ever.

Dispute on Drug Ad Campaign The White House is withholding millions of dollars in payments to a major advertising firm, Ogilvy & Mather, because of accusations that the firm may be overbilling the government for its work on a huge media campaign intended to discourage young people from using drugs.

Ineligible Children to Leave Health Plan for Medicaid Roughly half of all children in New York State who are enrolled in a special government health care plan do not actually qualify for the plan and will be removed from it in the next several months. The plan, the Children's Health Insurance Program, was intended to insure children from low-income families that could not afford private insurance and made too much money for Medicaid. But thousands of the New York children in the plan should be in Medicaid, officials and experts say.
La Guardia Delays Double The F.A.A. said delays at La Guardia Airport in August were more than double what they were in the same period last year, a jump mostly attributed to heavy air traffic.

3 Accused of Mob Art Scheme Two men described by federal prosecutors as having ties to organized crime and a New Jersey man who runs an offshore Internet gambling operation were charged with trying to sell five forged or stolen paintings, including two phony Picassos, for more than $30 million.

On the Money Trail Out West Hillary Rodham Clinton was in California raising hard money for her campaign as well as hard and soft money for the Democratic Party's Senate campaign committee. Aides said the trip was scheduled before her campaign reached an agreement with Rick A. Lazio's campaign to forswear the use of soft money for television campaign advertising.
Several polls show Mrs. Clinton with a modest but solid lead, with two having her at or above 50 percent.
Yanks Back Into Playoffs The Yankees lost to Baltimore, 13-2, but clinched the A.L. East title when Boston lost to Tampa Bay, 8-6.
A Bronze for Jones Marion Jones finished third in the women's long jump, dashing her hope for becoming the first female track and field athlete to win five gold medals in one Olympics.

Stocks Sink on Profit Fears Warnings from Apple and United Airlines pulled down a swath of companies as stocks closed a shaky third quarter. The Dow slumped 173.14 points, or 1.6 percent, to 10,650.92; the S.& P. 500 lost 21.78, or 1.5 percent, to 1,436.51; and the Nasdaq fell 105.50, or 2.8 percent, to 3,672.82.
UAL said the labor dispute this summer, coupled with the higher cost of jet fuel and an expensive new pilot contract, would cause a loss for this quarter and probably for the next.
Airbus Gets Singapore Contract Airbus won an $8.6 billion order for 25 superjumbo aircraft from Singapore Airlines, dealing a setback to Boeing, which sought the order.

New Inquiry on Truck Tires Federal regulators said they had opened a second investigation into Firestone tires, involving Steeltex tires used on the largest sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans.
Peter Gennaro The dancer and Tony Award-winning choreographer was 80.
Editorials: Contesting Jerusalem's holy sites; access to RU-486; Verlyn Klinkenborg on autumn farm chores. Columns: Anthony Lewis.
